This is a pretty bad course, maybe even the worst I have ever taken.  Andrew Barron seems to care about his students and is passionate about statistics, but somehow still managed to be a terrible professor. His lectures are almost entirely useless, as he simply rambles while writing random things on the board, making it very hard to follow. To make it worse, he does not post any notes regarding the material, and it occasionally does not line up with the textbook at all, making it especially difficult for the exams. 
The psets are not very difficult, but they are very lazily done (only textbook problems) and take up a decent amount of time (3-5 hours each) and he assigned one every week (13, including during both exam weeks). 
The first exam was mostly straightforward and reasonable, with a pretty high average, as the material lined up mostly with what we had done on the assignments. The second exam (final during the last week of class) was actually just a complete POS. Almost none of the problems lined up at all with any of the assignments. Furthermore, Barron had spent the last few classes talking about a concept not at all mentioned in the book or elsewhere, meaning that to understand it you would have had to rely on his terrible lectures (if you even went to class, otherwise you were 100% screwed). He then made 40% of the exam just on this subject, which had not even been a part of any of the assignments. This was arguably even worse than the infamous S&DS 241 final from Yihong.

Additionally, I did not appreciate the way that problem sets were graded in this course in which the smallest increment deduction on a problem was 1 out of 3 points (which is a relatively major deduction on a problem set worth 18 or 21 points total--and you could lose 1 out of 3 points for very small errors (i.e. not putting a hat on a variable, not drawing a graph in exactly the right way, etc.)). I wish problem sets had instead been graded out of 100 points to allow for a more nuanced scoring system (i.e. losing 2-3 percent for very small errors rather than 5-6+% as we did).

My complaints about this class are many, and it was because of this class that my semester was one of the more needlessly challenging semesters I've had during my time at Yale. Despite being a student who has spent a large amount of time considering statistics, and who has taken several S&DS courses, I felt woefully underprepared and under instructed at every stage of this class. It failed to leave me feeling as though I came away from the class with a true understanding of the material, and I struggled mightily with every assignment, test, and class weekly.

I worked as hard as I could for the entire semester, attending review sessions, office hours, additional lectures in the evenings, and studying with classmates, and no matter the extent to which I went to try to grasp the material that was expected of us, I could not reach a sufficient level of expertise. I am not one to hold grudges, and I genuinely tried time and time again to adjust my study habits and processes to meet this course's expectations, but I felt as though it expected me to come in with significantly more understanding and exposure to material that I simply have not reached. Professor Barron never considered students who have not spent several years as a statistics student, instead teaching to the top 15% of the class consisting of grad students. In doing so, I felt myself and several of my classmates being left behind to struggle to learn from a textbook that only covered a portion of what we needed to know. We were never given lecture slides, prior exams, or any other supplementary materials to better ourselves as students, and communication from Professor Barron was sparse at best. The expectations were unclear, and the tests did not in the slightest bit reflect what we had learned in class. Two of the questions on the final exam drew on material that, save for seven minutes at an optional review session, I have never before in my life had exposure to. This example was endemic of a theme of not only pushing kids beyond what could reasonably be expected of them, but also a negligence towards preparing us as statisticians. Homework assignments were rigid, as were all due dates, so even when we fell behind in lectures, we were asked to solve problems on concepts that hadn't ever been presented to us. 


I tried and I tried to get help, especially from the TA's who were quite often the only available resources, but they failed to hear what students were asking, or to provide support for a class that was clearly panicking because we were not able to do what was asked of us. I felt as though I was not alone in several of these experiences, and daily students would complain about the homework assignments, midterm, and final. This toxic environment led to several other students feeling the need to cheat weekly, and as a result the curve of grades did not reflect properly the students who worked hard and gave honest efforts, but rather rewarded those who chose to shortcut the process. 


I have had hard classes in the past, and I intend to continue to take difficult classes in the future, because the point of coming to Yale is to be pushed beyond your comfort zone. But a class like this not only makes me question my proficiency in a subject I love, it also makes me question my place here at Yale. It was structured such that students existed in a constant state of panic, and I never felt as though we turned a corner. I exhausted all available resources, and still felt as though I was never set up to succeed, which is a difficult place to be as a curious and driven student.

I would definitely not recommend it if it's not for your major. The lectures were too early in the morning (9:25 MWF), and there were no lecture notes posted online so it would be pretty hard to keep up with the material without going to class. The weekly problem sets were often quite long and difficult, often 10 handwritten pages of calculations, and I relied heavily on office hours to complete them. I do feel like I gained important foundational knowledge about statistical theory, but it was hard-earned from spending a lot of time on the problem sets and trying to decipher my notes and the textbook and asking lots of questions at office hours. The lectures were often pretty detail-oriented and very, very theoretical, while the homeworks were a bit more computational. The professor is really passionate about statistics and actually a pretty nice guy, but I don't think his lecture style is very easy to follow. He often stands in front of a board he's writing on so you can't see it, and moves them around or erases them too quickly to copy everything down. He also talks a lot without writing, so if you fall behind during a lecture it is very hard to catch up and you will probably just miss a lot. I wish there had been more office hours throughout the week-- they were all concentrated on Sunday and Monday, with problem sets due every Wednesday in class, so it was hard to start early or finish things up on Tuesday. There were two in-class exams (not cumulative) which were VERY different-- the first was quite easy and followed the review session almost exactly, while the second was too long and very difficult. Problem sets and exams were graded and handed back in a very timely manner, which I appreciated, but there wasn't usually a lot of actual feedback on them.
